fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.bodyText: Corrections made on theguardian.com on 21 May 2010 • Google admits collecting Wi-Fi data through Street View cars was amended because it gave outdated figures when it said Street View currently displays images from cities in nine countries, including 21 in the UK. Corrections published in the Guardian on 21 May 201 • In a report on congressional hearings into April's Deepwater Horizon oil rig explosion in the Gulf of Mexico we said that the "cement casing for the well" involved was made by Halliburton. Rather, it was this company that cemented the well's casing into place (BP and Halliburton executives 'ignored safety failures before Deepwater blast', 13 May, page 29) • A story headlined Cable to sell off Royal Mail (20 May, page 1) referred to "Labour's attempts to privatise the postal operator". The Labour government's plan was for part-privatisation: it aimed to inject private capital up to a 49% stake. • Talking about Germany's declining birthrate, an article rightly referred to the Nazi authorities' encouragement to women to produce lots of children – but wrongly suggested that Kinder, Küche, Kirche was a Nazi catchphrase. The country's current family minister was named as Kerstin Schröder when she should have been Kristin. Roland Koch, prime minister of the state of Hesse, was described as also being a member of the national government. He is not in the government, but is a prominent member of the main governing party, the CDU (German birthrate at all-time low despite tax breaks, 20 May, page 23). • Maxine Peake (The misfit, 15 May, page 30, Weekend) was described as having a Yorkshire accent. She was born and brought up in Bolton, which is historically a part of Lancashire, now Greater Manchester, the main of eight townships within Bolton metropolitan borough.
